ratings.question_text: I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: What is the name of your TA?
comments: Iona Hawkens
Iona Hawken
Iona Hawken

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: Nothing toshow..
The readings and the subject material. This course taught me how to think.

The way the class is structured in terms of the discussions and assignments creates a great balance of learning to explore social science questions independently and also be encouraged by the instructor to push our thoughts deeper and further. This is probably the best class at FES in terms of being taught to think independently and at the same time challenged to question our assumption.
We were exposed to some key theoretical writers in development and conservation, and were encouraged to develop our thinking about the theory. The small size was great for discussion.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: The instructor is a bit disorganized in the presentation of the papers. We also start late a lot. Focus.

The course revolved around Carol's analysis of each week's texts. Would have been nice to incorporate a more intentional discussion element to the course, since we were often busting at the seams with questions and comments on the texts. Maybe revisit Foucault at the end of the course. Latour was mentioned once in a while in class...perhaps include him?

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Good. I was able to meet with them whenever I needed it.
Excellent help from the instructor. The TA was decently responsive over email, but a bit aloof in class.
Great. very specific comments on our analyses were helpful for improving them.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: In many ways this was a culminating course for my time at FES, bringing together various theories and going into more depth with several of them. But I was less interested in the capitalism segment at the end.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I took the course because I wanted to learn more about political theory and anthropology. I am very interested in the subject.
For an additional class experience with the instructor.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes
It was a bit too labor-intensive. I spent much much more time on this class than any of my other classes, and would have preferred a more even course load.
Yes it did and even exceeded them

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: It helped to understand the readings.

Occasionally we met while we were writing our reading summaries to discuss the readings. This was helpful for the writing process and gave us a chance to discuss the readings, which we didn't have in class. Perhaps this could be an opportunity for the TA to lead discussions? Would have liked to hear more of Iona's insights.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: If you aren't interested in the subject material don't take the course. It would probably be super boring. I only wish I had more time to focus on this course. It is a lot of mental work.

When you're writing your reading summaries, follow Carol's model:Themes from writer #1Themes from writer #2Compare/contrast how the two writers approach Foucault: governmentality, power, knowledgeCompare/contrast how the two writers approach other themes from the course, e.g., Marxism, capitalism, place/space
